And right now, the loudest macro pundits, at least the ones who have increased their volume in the last few weeks, are the ones talking about the Fed being back behind the curve because of this resurgence in inflation. And that's really scary, because then we're going back to the whack a mole fed who's just going to crush markets or at least cap all upside. For me, I think inflation will continue to normalize into the summer, and arriving in that view requires a pretty granular approach to modeling inflation. In my career, I've had the benefit of trading a lot of inflation products, and doing that requires figuring out all the actual modeling, all the subcategories, and aggregating that to a fixing model. On the other hand, I'd say the core of the inflation acceleration arguments are they're based on these hand wavy macro models which haven't really been relevant in about 50 years. And in some ways, you feel validated by last year's inflation, or you're just willing to say, this time is different. This is the most unique cycle we've had in a long time. So, of course, the models which are relevant models can be relevant that weren't relevant before. And I'd say there's two main arguments that come up a lot. One was that there was just too much stimulus, and now you have this inflation problem which can't be put back. And I think that actually misses quite a bit of what's going on.
